awd_titl_txt: Data-Driven Optimal Police Patrol Zone Districting and Staffing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award contributes to the nation’s security and welfare by developing data-driven decision tools designed to improve police and first-responder operations. The project simultaneously addresses improved patrol zone design and efficient officer staffing. Police zone designs in large U.S. cities can become outdated if not effectively revised to keep up with population growth, changing transportation patterns, and urban development, leaving vulnerable communities at risk. In addition, police staffing nationwide continues to be constrained by limited budgets and high attrition rates. This project will leverage the vast amounts of data that are available today to create new analytical models and algorithms that promise significant improvements over traditional approaches. The research outcomes in this project will be informed by data from the City of Atlanta, Georgia but will be of value to police agencies nationwide. In particular, the project will develop computational decision support tools with interactive graphical interfaces to visualize police zone reconfiguration and police workload change. The research team will make available computer codes for data analysis, zone design and staff planning free of charge to other interested agencies. 

The research methods employed in this project will bridge several fields in operations research and data analytics, including spatial-temporal models in statistics, queueing theory in applied probability, and discrete stochastic optimization. The project will create high fidelity models for police emergency service systems using large-scale police reports and census and transportation data. By leveraging modern statistical and queueing methods, the service system will be modeled and analyzed using stochastic methods in order to estimate intensity, location, and categories of emergency calls, as well as the service capacity and travel time of police officers and first-responders. The project uses optimization methods to develop efficient algorithms for zone design and staffing based on these stochastic models. The model’s effectiveness in preventive policing and equitable coverage will be back tested through empirical analysis of policing data. The project will involve graduate students who will be learn how modern optimization methods can be used to improve design in a service sector critical to the nation's security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to enhance public safety by creating data-driven strategies that improve how police respond to 911 calls. Our team combined methods from operations research, queueing theory, transportation science, causal inference, and machine learning to develop innovative tools for real-time decision-making, equitable resource allocation, and efficient police patrols.

On the intellectual merit front, we introduced new approaches for managing large-scale, complex datasets (millions of 911 records) to determine how, when, and where officers should be deployed. We leveraged advanced queueing models and multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize patrol routes, while mixed-integer programming techniques guided us in designing improved zones or “beats.” We also applied statistical models to address the high-dimensional nature of spatio-temporal police data and police operations. Causal analyses then measured the effectiveness of staff allocation strategies. Furthermore, spatio-temporal point process models facilitated more accurate crime linkage detection, enabling authorities to identify and intervene in emerging crime patterns quickly and effectively.

From a broader impacts perspective, this project has directly influenced policing strategies in Atlanta and nearby communities. Beginning in 2019, the Atlanta Police Department adopted our data-driven zone redesigns, reducing workload imbalances and lowering average response times. The City of South Fulton also implemented similar changes, achieving substantial improvements in balancing service demands across different zones. In 2022, we refined these analyses by aligning beats with neighborhood planning units, reinforcing the link between public safety and community boundaries.

Beyond improving emergency services, the project provided robust training opportunities. Multiple PhD and undergraduate researchers contributed, gaining hands-on experience in reinforcement learning, causal inference, and computational optimization—skills in high demand across academia and industry. Several students earned prestigious awards and graduated from the doctoral programs, securing academic job at major universities and industrial jobs as data scientists, highlighting our project’s educational impact. Meanwhile, we presented at major conferences like INFORMS and published in top journals, including the INFORMS Journal on Applied Analytics and the Annals of Applied Statistics. To foster wider adoption, we released open-source code and organized outreach events at local high schools and Clark Atlanta University (an HBCU), stimulating broader interest in data-driven solutions for public-sector challenges.

Overall, this work underscores how rigorous theory, combined with real-world data, can create fairer, more efficient emergency services. By integrating novel analytical methods, we have helped local police departments significantly reduce 911 response times and promote equitable resource distribution—benefiting both law enforcement officers and the communities they serve, working towrads reducing crime and building safter communities.
